# Now, let's analyze bike sales using Python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
source.d26505d9:
# customer age histogram

sales['Customer_Age'].plot(kind='hist', figsize=(10,5)) #the company has more 20 to 40 years old customers
source.c85cf97b:
# cust age boxplot
sales['Customer_Age'].plot(kind='box', figsize=(15,10)) #on average, customer age is around 35 years
source.71b1548d:
#pie chart sales per year
sy = sales['Year'].value_counts().sort_index(ascending = False)
sy.plot(kind='pie', figsize = (10,10), startangle = 90)
source.6c810f1e:
#sales per month bar plot
#sm = sales["Month"].value_counts()
months_categories = ["January", "February", "March", "April", "May", "June", "July", "August", "September", "October", "November", "December"]
sm = pd.Categorical(sales["Month"], categories = months_categories).value_counts()
sm.plot(kind='bar', figsize = (15,10))
source.fd7bc037:
#sales per country bar plot
sc = sales["Country"].value_counts()
sc.plot(kind='bar',figsize = (14,10))
source.84a69034:
#relationship between Unit Cost and Unit Price
sales.plot(x = "Unit_Cost", y = "Unit_Price", figsize = (10,10), kind = "scatter")
source.85dc774f:
#relationship between order qty and profit
sales.plot(x = "Order_Quantity", y = "Profit", kind = "scatter", figsize = (10,10))
source.7d81b38b:
#increase 50USD revenue to every sale
sales["Revenue_50"] = sales["Revenue"] + 50
sales.head()
source.7fa6f2c0:
#How many orders were made in Canada or France?
sales.loc[(sales["Country"] == "Canada") | (sales["Country"] == "France")].shape[0]
source.ddb02d46:
#How many Bike Racks orders were made from Canada?
sales.loc[(sales["Country"] == "Canada") & (sales["Sub_Category"] == "Bike Racks")].shape[0]
source.6b7462a6:
# How many orders were made in each region (state) of France?
france_st_sales = sales.loc[sales["Country"] == "France", "State"].value_counts()
france_st_sales.head(6)
source.b7f4216f:
#bar plot with france state sales
france_st_sales.plot(kind = "bar", figsize = (10,10))
source.ebb5b764:
#sales per product category pie chart
spc = sales["Product_Category"].value_counts().sort_index()
spc.plot(kind="pie", figsize = (10,10), startangle = 225)
source.72e13864:
#How many orders were made per bike sub-categories?
bikes =sales.loc[sales["Product_Category"] == "Bikes", "Sub_Category"].value_counts()
bikes
source.7f6be4b5:
#pie chart
bikes.plot(kind="pie", figsize=(12,12), startangle = 270) #I used different figure sizes to learn which size looks better
source.dad9adc5:
#best seller bikes in a bar chart
top_bikes.plot(kind="bar", figsize=(12,8))
source.709a02d2:
#Which gender has the most amount of sales?
gs = sales["Customer_Gender"].value_counts()
gs
source.ec9d5576:
#How many sales with more than 500 in Revenue were made by men?
sales.loc[(sales["Revenue"] > 500) & (sales["Customer_Gender"] == "M")].shape[0]
source.a566d100:
#Get the top-5 sales with the highest revenue
sales.sort_values(["Revenue"], ascending = False).head(5)
source.004d5aab:
#Get the sale with the highest revenue
sales.sort_values(["Revenue"], ascending = False).head(1)
source.c9a4aab5:
#What is the mean Order_Quantity of orders with more than 10K in revenue?
sales.loc[(sales["Revenue"] > 10000), "Order_Quantity"].mean()
source.e3279df2:
#What is the mean Order_Quantity of orders with less than 10K in revenue?
sales.loc[(sales["Revenue"] < 10000), "Order_Quantity"].mean()
source.764ca149:
#How many orders were made in May of 2016?
sales.loc[(sales["Month"] == "May") & (sales["Year"] == 2016)].shape[0]
source.fcaffac5:
#Add 7.2% TAX on every sale Unit_Price within United States
#sales["Unit_Price_US"] = sales.loc[sales["Country"] == "United States", "Unit_Price"] * 1.072

sales.loc[sales['Country'] == 'United States', 'Unit_Price'] * 1.072
source.463bcc90:
# Bike Sales Analysis with Python 
#### A Data Analysis using the Free Code Camp Pandas Real Life Example.

#### The analysis below shows the process I used to solve the exercises of the Youtube video ["Data Analysis with Python - Full Course for Beginners (Numpy, Pandas, Matplotlib, Seaborn)"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r-uOLxNrNk8) from Free Code Camp. 


#### If you haven't checked their videos yet, I suggest you to do so. This video I've mentioned is very well explained and easy to follow, helping lots of beginner programmers (like me) to learn Python. 

#### The list with these exercises is available on [Github](https://github.com/ine-rmotr-curriculum/FreeCodeCamp-Pandas-Real-Life-Example/blob/master/Exercises_1.ipynb). Check it out and try them too! They sure helped me a lot!
source.9400e538: ## Thanks for checking my analysis! Check Free Code Camp on [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/c/Freecodecamp) and [Github](https://github.com/ine-rmotr-curriculum/FreeCodeCamp-Pandas-Real-Life-Example/blob/master/Exercises_1.ipynb) to learn more about coding with Python!
